{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3436691,"name":"Max N","username":"maxikyuu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/maxikyuu/{size}/234410_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-19T02:00:23.551Z","cooked":"

Hello, we are using the ThriftyBot Absolute Magnetic encoders on MK4i Neo swerve drive connected to the Analog pin on the roboRIO. However, there is currently a short between the 5V and the GND of one of our thrifty encoders. I’d like to give a bit of context first:

During a competition in the official season, one of our encoders on our swerve module, let’s call it Encoder #1, kept reporting a constant value even though we were physically rotating the swerve module. We replaced it with a spare encoder (Encoder #2), and it worked for the rest of our season.

However, just before our off-season competition, we noticed that Encoder #2 started exhibiting the same symptoms of the Encoder #1. It kept reporting some arbitrary value (140?), causing us not be able to drive properly. We used a multimeter to probe the Signal and GND of the encoder, and it reported the full sweep from 0V-5V. We figured it was some sort of conductive shavings in the roboRIO, so we vacuumed the analog ports.

After power-cycling the robot, it started working for a while, until we power-cycled it again the next-day and found that it was shorting the roboRIO 5V rails (POWER status light was red). We swapped wires and determined they weren’t the issue since it was still shorting. We also determined that the roboRIO wasn’t the issue because plugging only that encoder into the RIO causes the red status light to turn on, unplugging the encoder turned it back to green. The encoder was also getting REALLY hot, and melted some of our hot glue on it.

As a last resort, we replaced Encoder #2 back to Encoder #1. It started working again… until it didn’t today. Encoder #1 started shorting exactly like Encoder #2 did, with all of the same symptoms. After using a multimeter, we determined that there was only a short happening between the 5V and GND contacts of the thrifty encoder. We vacuumed the encoder and didn’t find any conductive shavings on it.

We were hopeless as we had no spares left with 2 days until comp, fortunately, we were able to reach out to a team competing in the same off-season competition who were willing to let us borrow one of their thrifty encoders.

Our next steps are as follows:

  • Test the analog port of Encoder #1 again with a different encoder of one of the other swerve modules to verify that it’s not the 5V rail on the RIO that’s shorting.
  • Replace the PWM-style wire again to confirm it’s not the wire either.
  • Replace Encoder #1 with the borrowed one.

Has anyone had the same issue with their thrifty encoders? What might be the root cause of all this so that we don’t break our borrowed encoder in the same way?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-10-19T02:00:23.551Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":200.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":473295,"topic_slug":"thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting","display_username":"Max N","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61798,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting/473295/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3436697,"name":"Tauseef Afraz","username":"TFM110","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tfm110/{size}/197758_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-19T02:08:01.991Z","cooked":"

I have a few thoughts you could test

  1. Have you measured the analog port on the RIO with a multimeter to see if there is a short there?
  2. Since it seems to be happening on the same port, have you tried plugging Encoder #1 and/or #2 into a different analog port?
  3. Have you tried a different RIO?

The majority of what I have been asking is RIO related cause from what I read is that you have mainly been testing the encoder, not the RIO port itself

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-10-19T02:08:01.991Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":473295,"topic_slug":"thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting","display_username":"Tauseef Afraz","primary_group_name":"Swyft-Robotics","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT"},"post_url":"/t/thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting/473295/2","custom_user_title":"FRC5431AM | FRC5790M| FUN | SWYFT","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3436710,"name":"Max N","username":"maxikyuu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/maxikyuu/{size}/234410_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-19T02:21:49.830Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the reply!

  1. Yes, we have tested the analog port using a multimeter between 5V and GND, there wasn’t a short there. But we will test again and post an update here.
  2. No, we have not. We will do that ASAP.
  3. No, we will try plugging the encoder into a different RIO at the competition.

If you have any other ideas on what might be the issue, please let me know. Thanks!

  1. Have you tested measuring between 5V and signal or GND and signal?

I believe there wasn’t any shorts there, but I’m not 100% sure. We’ll try again for sure. We did measure between 5V-Signal and GND-Signal on the ends of the PWM-style wire, and there wasn’t any shorts there.

Hey! I forgot to mention but we already packed our stuff yesterday for our competition tomorrow. We will go through all the troubleshooting first thing in the morning and will update you on that. We’ll most likely use our spare RIO with the borrowed encoder so we don’t damage it. Thanks!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-10-20T00:56:22.866Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":29.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":473295,"topic_slug":"thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting","display_username":"Max N","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":39084,"username":"TFM110","name":"Tauseef Afraz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tfm110/{size}/197758_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61798,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/thrifty-absolute-encoder-shorting/473295/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3441903,"name":"Max N","username":"maxikyuu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/maxikyuu/{size}/234410_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-30T21:30:29.820Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone, sorry for the late update. We won our offseason competition, Overtime Sunday, along with our alliance partners, 3015 and 4678! We couldn’t have done it without the gracious help of alumnis from 7902, who let us to borrow one of their thrifty encoders so that we can replace our broken one.

We ultimately switched our roboRIO with a spare one, and we have not had any issues with the borrowed encoder shorting during our competition! Here were the steps that we tried before swapping RIOs:

  1. We measured no shorts between any of the pins (5V, GND, Signal) of all the analog ports on the roboRIO.
  2. Plugging the broken encoder into any of the other analog ports shorts the roboRIO
  3. Plugging a non-broken encoder into the analog port of the broken encoder does not cause a short on the roboRIO
  4. After swapping roboRIOs, the broken encoder still causes a short if its plugged into any of the analog ports
  5. On the new roboRIO, after replacing the borrowed encoder with the broken one, there weren’t any more shorts or issues during our competition!

After the competition, we disassembled and cleaned out the old roboRIO but did not find any metal shavings or debris. We’re still waiting for our replacement encoders from Thrifty to arrive before we try testing if the old RIO causes a short on the encoder on that specific analog port after some time, leading to it becoming defective.

Anyways, thank you all for your help and advice!
